abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project was
            satisfactory. The principal objectives of the project, to
            increase the capacity for potable water production for the
            city of Al Mukalla, was achieved after the project was
            redesigned, and, institutional capability was strengthened.
            Effective demand for water is expected by the year 2002,
            thus to ensure sustainability, the Government is committed
            to grant the Al Mukalla branch of the National Water and
            Sanitation Authority, full autonomy, to further improve cost
            recovery, and focus on the expansion of water distribution
            and sewerage networks. This autonomy will also strengthen
            financial management, to set its own tariffs ensuring its
            own viability. The lessons experienced from this project
            suggest that: 1) close supervision, and flexibility to
            changes may prod success, even when facing serious
            implementation problems as was this case; 2) it is critical
            for the implementation of complex projects to attain
            experienced contractors; 3) local currency funds should be
            ensured at the early stages, since delays will cause
            implementation interruptions; 4) Long term sustainability of
            project benefits, is ensured by sector reforms, which foster
            institutional strengthening, and financial/management
            systems; and, 5) while problems were encountered, close
            cooperation and agreement with the borrower was paramount to
            the success of the operation.
